content: First, many users write in text-only mode. They see email for communication, and since HTML is a markup language, you can never know how your message is received. And, all of what you want to do can be done in Thunderbird. Multiple fonts, different sizes, underlines, etc. But, since HTML is a markup language, it sometimes requires some tweaking. You can do some extra editing - and also see how the markup language is applied, by adding this addon - thunderbirdHTMLedit, from https://betterbird.eu/addons/index.html
creator: davidsk

content: I had the same issue with read messages not displaying. It was due to a glitch in the app’s sync feature. I fixed it by clearing the cache and restarting the app. If that does not work, try checking your notification settings or reinstalling the app!

content:
Thunderbird is advising you that the Security for the site is unverified and needs updating. You can allow an exception so that Thunderbird accesses the site but that is never advisable.

Optusnet has been throwing up problems with TB in the past couple of weeks. A link to the Optus help sheet is here - https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1486768. I note that the TB settings there posted are different to the ones being used.

content:
I'm not sure I understand your situation. Keeping a mail account that can no longer connect to the server merely for archiving purposes doesn't make much sense to me…

Are you aware you may store your mail in Local Folders and organise your mail there however you wish, independently of any account? And you may also let Thunderbird handle the archiving of your messages in a more automated way:

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/archived-messages
creator: DavidGG

content: Profilinizde parolaların kaydedildiği bazı dosyalar hasar görmüş olabilir. Menü > Yardım > Sorun giderme bilgilerine tıklayın. Profil klasörü satırının yanındaki "Klasörü aç" düğmesine tıklayın. Şimdi Thunderbird'ü kapatın. Açılan klasördeki cert9.db, key4.db ve secmod.db dosyalarını silin (hangileri mevcutsa). Thunderbird'ü açtığınızda bu dosyalar otomatik olarak yeniden oluşturulacaktır.
creator: maxcoder

content: Just a diagnostic... ...please switch off checking automatically for email at start up, close TB and restart. If the message pops up then it's without any TB access to a server. If it doesn't pop up, it surely has to do with a connection to a server that TB is trying to establish. Not a solution but it might help understand the problem.

content:
• In Settings > Privacy and Security

In Passwords section

  • Click on 'Saved Passwords'
  • Click on 'Show Passwords'

You should see : If POP account: Two lines one for incoming - mailbox://account.... and one for outgoing: smtp://account.... If Imap account: Two lines one for incoming - imap://account.... and one for outgoing: smtp://account....

If any account has been set up to use Authentication Method: Oauth2 then you should only see one line for the account: oauth://account......

Do you see all your accounts in the Saved Passwords ? If yes, please right click on the relevant incoming line and select 'Edit Password' completely clear contents and then carefully type the correct password. Repeat for the outgoing line. clickon 'Close'

OR do all appear except the one that keeps asking for password ?
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
TB often defines what a 'junk' message is by a mark on the incoming email put there by the server through which it comes. So, that's a possibility...

...however, you didn't mention a filter. Have you set up a filter for that particular email address?

A filter can be set up by accessing the filter interface at Hamburger (top right)/Tools/Message Filters. See https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/organize-your-messages-using-filters

content: This happens because Thunderbird must be told where the profile is; it doesn't 'look' for it. Thunderbird opens this file: c:\users\<your id>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles.ini to get the name and location of the profile. You can edit that yourself with Notepad, or you can, from desktop, do this: - click windows key and 'r' key - enter thunderbird.exe -p and press enter - this is the profile manager. click the 'create profile' button and follow the steps to locate your profile, give a shortcut name, then click 'choose' and then finish and launch

content:
Here is the link for moving a profile in Windows when installed in default location: 

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/moving-thunderbird-data-to-a-new-computer

here is the info in brief steps:

  1. ensure thunderbird is NOT running on old machine
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  7. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  8. start thunderbird and all should be there

I suggest you compare these steps to how you did the transfer, as that may open some ideas.
creator: davidsk
